acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96-hour LC50=2microg/L of fishes (Bluegill) (AQUIRE, 2003).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Rat LD50 = approx. 29mg/kg and 100mg/kg. The former higher toxicity was adopted and it was set as Category 1.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Rat LD50 = 3.76 mg/kg (male), 3.03 mg/kg (female) (ATSDR (1997)). Estimated lethal dose for humans in oral is 1-2 mg/kg (PATTY (5th, 2001), ACGIH (2001), ATSDR (1997), HSDB (2005), IUCLID (2004)). Even if based on any data, it is set as  Category 1.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 1, since acute toxicity was Category 1, and behavior in water and bioaccumulative potential are unknown.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: UNRTDG No. 1381, Class: 4.2, Subsidiary risks Class:  Class: 6.1, PGI

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_solids.rationale: UNRTDG No. 1381, Class: 4.2, Subsidiary risks Class:  Class: 6.1, PG I

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Containing no oxygen , chlorine and fluorine.

pyrophoric_solids.hazard_statement: Catches fire spontaneously if exposed to air
pyrophoric_solids.rationale: UNRTDG No. 1381, Class: 4.2, Subsidiary risks Class: 6.1, PGI

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
It is described that in the rat study (generation study) with administration covering two reproductive cycles from 80 days before mating, mortality of mother animals was observed with high doses, most of them (13/16) occured during delivery period, and that administration of yellow phosphorus may be the possible cause (IRIS (1991)). 
Since although concentration of the death to an delivery period is considered to be an adverse effects to reproduction, influence of maternal toxicities cannot be denied, either, it was classified into Category 2. 
In addition, inhibition of growth and survival of a child was observed in lactation period with the administration starting three weeks before mating and the effect on lactation is suggested as a cause of this (ATSDR (1997)).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classified in UNRTDG No. 1381, Class: 4.2, Subsidiary risks Class:  6.1, PGI

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: A serious injury accompanied by a eyelids convulsion, photophobia and lacrimation by touching the human eye, or corneal cloudings is caused (PATTY (5th, 2001), HSDB (2005)). Or redness, a pain, eyesight loss, and a serious burn are indicated (ICSC (2004)). So it was set as Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: There are descriptions that it causes burn when contacting human skin (ACGIH (2001), ATSDR (1997), ICSC (2004)), and that it originates not only in thermals but in corrosive effects (ATSDR (1997)). Moreover, also in the animal studies, it is evaluated as "corrosive" or "necrosis" (IUCLID (2004), ATSDR (1997)). Based on what mentioned above, it was classified as Category 1A-1C.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: UNRTDG No. 1381, Class:  4.2, Subsidiary risks Class:  Class:  6.1, PGI

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (bone, blood)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: According to human case reports or epidemiological study,  a necrosis of a jaw part and bony destruction, so-called "phossy jaw" is reported (IRIS (1991), PATTY (5th, 2001), ATSDR (1997)) , and the denaturation of the mouth and anemia are also reported (PATTY (5th, 2001), ATSDR (1997)).) Moreover, effects on bone is observed also the animal studies (IRIS (1991).). The effects above were considered to be serious toxicity, it was classified in Category 1 (a bone, hematologic).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (liver, kidney, digestive system, blood, central nervous system),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (liver, kidney, digestive system, blood, central nervous system)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: It was classified into Category 1(liver, kidney, digestive systems, hematopoietic systems, central nervous systems), since there are reports or descriptions that it affects to wide range of organs, such as the liver, kidney, gastrointestinal system, haematopoietic system, central nerves by acute exposure of this product to human (ACGIH (2001), PATTY (5th, 2001), IRIS (1991), HSDB (2005)). Moreover, it was classified into Category 3 (respiratory irritant) due to the respiratory irritant by short time exposures is also observed (ATSDR (1997)). In addition, the reason of the death in the examination of mouse is that mucosal swellings or mucus secretions occurred by irritation, the airway was closed and died by suffocation (ATSDR (1997)).
